div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF SEVENTY-THREE HINDOOS.) ) ) No. 2532. MEMORANDUM BRIEF OF PETITIONERS. REPLY BRIEF.

PRACTICE OF DEPARTMENT. It will be noted that the respondent states that it has been the practice of the department to issue warrants where the aliens were likely to become public charges, and not to wait until the aliens had become public charges. This clearly shows that the practice of the department has not been in accordance with law, and in accordance with Section 20. The respondent urges that he knows of no decisions in which more than a liklihood to become public charges is necessary.

The language of Section 20 is to plain and the government's rules are so clear that it was intended that the alien should actually become a public charge before a warrant should be issued, that a decision could hardly be founded on a matter that is plain on its face as to the intent of Section 20

The practice of the department in the past is
not law for this court, but the construction of Section 20 can be but one way, if the court is strictly construes that section, as petitioners believe it should be construed.
RESPONDENT'S CITATION PROVES PETITIONERS' CASE.

By reference to United States vs. Williams, 175 Federal, 274, it will be noted that this case decides the very points contended for and by the petitioners. The holding there was that if the Secretary violated the statute, that the courts would interfer, also that the courts would see that there was some evidence upon which the decision of the secretary was based. In that case, the Court further decided that it was not only necessary to find that the alien had become a pauper, but that it might be shown that alien had become a prisoner as well, showing clearly that if would be neccessary for him to become something, either a pauper or a prisoner.

The United States attorney contends that the warrant was not issued as a result of a clandestine entry, but on a liability to become a public charge, showing clearly that these cases could not come within the purview or the intent of Section 20.
FRANK GREEN'S STATEMENT.

That respondent states that he had a talk with Mr. Frank Green, and the attorney for petitioners likewise had a talk with the said party. Mr. Green states that he was a soldier in the Philippine Islands and that it was customary to demand a registration certificate before permitting aliens in the Philippine Islands to
testify in court or to do any act concerning governmental or city or state business, but on reading the affidavit of the interpretor which petitioners furnished, Mr. Green states that doubtless that is a fact today, and that such rules are doubtless followed. That what he was referring to was that during the time of the insurrection when he was a soldier was issuing some of these certificates himself. That he really did not know as to the law or as to what the immigration or governmental requirement was, but he believes that perhaps some such rule as that mentioned by the interpretor was probabaly correct.

GOVERNMENT ADMITS OUR CONTENTION. It will be noted by referring to the memorandum brief of respondent on the first page thereof, the second from the last line, this language used by the attorney for the government, "and whether at said hearing some evidence has been secured". It has been our contention that no evidence has ever been presented. At the bottom of page 3 of respondent's brief, it will be noted the government contends that the language used in Section 20 quoted by petitioners as to those who do become public charges is contended by the government to have meant to meet cases where it could not be said that there was a liklihood to become a public charge at the time of entry. There is nothing in the law justifiying this assertion and Section 20 is so plain that it would be hard to read this contention into it.

At the bottom of page 4 of respondent's brief, counsel states that Section 20 explicitely authorizes deportation for unlawful entry. This is quite correct, but he goes on and parenthetically states (including original liability to become a public charge within three years). There is nothing in the law to justify this parenthetic statememt and the section is so plain as to make it obvious to the court that this is not intended.

On page 5 of respondent's brief, the sixth line thereof, counsel states that the official warrants upon authority of which the aliens are held has no bearing on the original entry into the Philippines and that the original entry is not questioned by the secretary's warrant, but that the only ground on which the aliens are held is of their liability to become public charges, which is plainly not in accordance with Section 20, and here again the government practically admits our contention.

Again, in the middle of page 6, the government admits our contention as to the method of issuing the informal certificate prior to the issuance of the cedula or head tax. Thus it will be seen that the United States attorney has in his bried admitted every contention made be counsel for the aliens, his only contention now being that Section 20 does not mean what it plainly and un- equivocally states, and if it is to be strictly construed the government's contentions cannot stand a moment.

The only other contention made by the government is an attempt to read into Section 20 certain practices
of the department which the petitioners claim is no ground by reason of the unauthorized and unlawful authority exercised by the secretary and immigration officials in the past, due largely to the fact that the courts have not had these matters brought to their attention in the past.

At the top of page 7 of respondent's brief, respondent states that the same exhibits attached to the brief of petitioners were sent to Washington, this is not true. There were documents sent to Wash- ington, but none so conclusive of a proper examination at Manila and a lawful entry, as the ones attached to petitioners' brief. It seems to petitioners that these documents cannot be answered and that a lawful entry is shown thereby, the government admitting again that these documents show more or less clearly that the aliens were before the immigration authorities at Manila.

Again, at the end of the first paragraph of Paragraph 7 it will be noted that the government admits that there was no clandestine entry, but it is here con- tended that the unlawful entry is not the basis for the secretary's warrant on authority of which the aliens are now being held, again admitting that an unlawful entry is not shown in any way and practically admitting a lawful entry.This does away with the only ground upon which the government has to stand, which throws the argument back upon the liability to become a public charge, and in view of the specific terms of Section 20, this contention must fall.
SECTION 20, NOT SECTION 3.

The government in the respondent's brief, endeavors to inject Section 3 into the argument. The court will have little difficulty in determining that Section 3 has nothing to do with this case and Section 20 is the only section upon which the secretary can issue the warrants.
NO EVIDENCE INTRODUCED.

On the last page of respondent's brief, this language is found,"some evidence, however slight, having been introduced in support of the ruling of the secretary". No matter how carefully the court scans the testimony, he will find that there has not been a word of testimony and there has been no evidence introduced and there has never ever been any evidence before any of the government officials on the point involved in this petition, on the fact of aliens having already become public charges.

In the case cited by the government, it will be noted that the courts held there must be some evidence and that the decision was only final where it complied with the law, in the one case where there had been no appeal taken when that was the requisite, and in the other that there had been an unlawful entry shown by the evidence, which is not true in the case before this Honorable Court. Respectfully submitted,
Herbert W. Meyers Attorney for Petitioners.
